name: Madanapala (Pala dynasty)
content:
Madanapala (reigned 1144 – 1162 CE) was the successor to the Pala king Gopala III in the Bengal region of the Indian subcontinent, and eighteenth and final ruler of Pala lineage reigning for 18 years. He was succeeded by Govindapala, whose lineage of that name is questionable.[1]
 During his reign, the encroachment by the Sena dynasty eventually reduced the Pala domains to Bihar. In Harikela, the Varman dynasty  were conquered by the Sena dynasty leaving the Palas as the only other significant power in Bengal.
 
 This biography of a member of an Indian royal house is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.
tags: All Wikipedia articles written in Indian English
raw:
Madanapala (reigned 1144 – 1162 CE) was the successor to the Pala king Gopala III in the Bengal region of the Indian subcontinent, and eighteenth and final ruler of Pala lineage reigning for 18 years. He was succeeded by Govindapala, whose lineage of that name is questionable.[1]
During his reign, the encroachment by the Sena dynasty eventually reduced the Pala domains to Bihar. In Harikela, the Varman dynasty  were conquered by the Sena dynasty leaving the Palas as the only other significant power in Bengal.

See also[edit]
List of rulers of Bengal
References[edit]


^ Chowdhury, AM (2012). "Pala Dynasty".  In Islam, Sirajul; Jamal, Ahmed A. (eds.). Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh (Second ed.). Asiatic Society of Bangladesh.




Preceded byGopala III

 Pala Emperor1144–1162 CE
